instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to trace the origins of Chinese wolfberry samples?

instruction: Can the combination of near-infrared hyperspectral imaging (NIR-HSI) and chemometric methods be considered superior to traditional methods in tracing the origins of Chinese wolfberry samples from different regions in China?
Output: Yes, the combination of near-infrared hyperspectral imaging (NIR-HSI) and chemometric methods can be considered superior to traditional methods in tracing the origins of Chinese wolfberry samples from different regions in China. The study mentioned in the text used NIR-HSI technique combined with chemometric methods to discriminate the origins of 1200 Chinese wolfberry samples from Ningxia, Inner Mongolia, Sinkiang, and Qinghai. The pixel-wise classification assigned a class to each pixel, allowing for intuitive visualization of the differences in wolfberries from different origins. Additionally, object-wise classification using mean spectra extracted representative spectra of each sample, which were then used to establish discriminant analysis models. The models based on extracted characteristic wavelengths from loadings of principal component analysis (PCA) achieved recognition accuracies higher than 90%. This approach not only ensured a high recognition rate but also simplified the model and was conducive to future rapid on-line testing. Therefore, the combination of NIR-HSI and chemometric methods proved to be effective in tracing the origins of Chinese wolfberries.
